along for some Miles Eastward thence on the Sides of the Hills 
are Crops of Coal and Limestone, and often Times the Tenants 
spitt up as much as will serve their Turn for a Winters burning 
just under the Surface, for there wants a Market and it is scarce 
worth working for Sale. And to the North West and North, in the 
Drift of the Coal in higher Ground, and consequently lying 
over it, there appear in the Sides of the Hills, Seams of Sparr and 
Lead, the Drift of which is North East and lyes almost perpen 
-dicular, but what Obliquity there is pitches to the South East.
At <u>Auchenclaugh <\u> Six Miles East from <u>Kylsith <\u> there is a Coal 
18 feet thick; this dips one foot in three, and is not pursued by 
Reason of Water, and for want of a Merket will not quit the 
cost of draining. At <u>Madestone <\u> the Coal is 4 1/2 Feet thick, about 
3 1/2 fathom deep; they land it (as at many Coal hews in the Countrey)
on Girls Backs. Near <u>Tranent <\u> are 3 different Veins wrought, the 
undermost is about 18 fathom from the Surface called the <u>Splenty 
Coal<\u> 4 1/2 feet thick, it’s a hard but not large Coal, makes a Clear and 
Strong fire, lyes ten Fathom under the <u>Main Coal <\u> which is 9 or 10
Feet thick & comes out verry large, it’s Roof is of Freestone, under 
which I walked backward and forward Two Hours, but had no 
Oppertunity to make any other Observations on the upper Vein,
than that it is about 4 feet thick and neither so hard or large as the 
other.
As I have <s>above <\s> fig 1st. & 2d drawn the different <u>Strata <\u> (which have 
come to my Observation) on a supposed Plain, as they there lye,
